comments:
Created an attachment (id=81246)
one of the console logs for one of the test suites. 

I've tried to move up to the latest platform build, 
	
eclipse-SDK-I20071023-0800-linux-gtk-ppc.tar.gz 

but none of the UI oriented test run, and contain "compilation problem" message from UITestApplication. 

Unresolved compilation problem!!?? How can this be? Even assuming it's only the PPC distribution, and it's somehow just gone astray, how could all the status marks show green? 

I'll attach a full log, but there's one part. 

java.lang.Error: Unresolved compilation problems: 
	The type org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files
	The type org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Shell cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files
	The method getDisplay() is undefined for the type Shell

	at org.eclipse.test.UITestApplication.<init>(UITestApplication.java:1)

Peeking inside the class file, for even the windows distribution, for which, I guess there's really no difference -- one zip for windows and linux, that is -- I can see the 

"Unresolved compilation problems: 
	The type org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files
	The type org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Shell cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files
	The method getDisplay() is undefined for the type Shell"

David we only run Junit tests on linux.gtk.x86, win32.win32.x86 and macosx.carbon.ppc.

For these platforms, green means tests run successfully.  For the other platforms, it means no compilation errors.


Which class file are you seeing the compile error in?  In one of our bundles or one of yours? Are you running a new version of basebuilder?

We have seen similar changes issues with the new version of pde build and have had to adjust our build scripts accordingly.

See
pde build bug 207500
releng bug 206082

(In reply to comment #2)

> 
> For these platforms, green means tests run successfully.  For the other
> platforms, it means no compilation errors.
> 

It also means you are not using the latest org.eclipse.test to run the tests, or you'd see the same thing I am. 

> 
> Which class file are you seeing the compile error in?  In one of our bundles or
> one of yours? 

It's yours, in automated.jar, in org.eclipse.test
in org.eclipse.test.UITestApplication.class

> Are you running a new version of basebuilder?
> 

No, briefly tried to move up to M2_34 but got 50000 compile errors, so figured I'd have to look at that later. 

Thanks for the pointers.

(In reply to comment #2)
> David we only run Junit tests on linux.gtk.x86, win32.win32.x86 and
> macosx.carbon.ppc.
> 
> For these platforms, green means tests run successfully.  For the other
> platforms, it means no compilation errors.
> 
> 

Yes, but the "eclipse-test-framework-I2007.....zip" file itself has a green check mark, so should mean no compile errors in it, right? 

But, it does have compile errors. So .. I think there is a bug in your summary reporting system too.

We are using the latest org.eclipse.test to run the tests.  I see the class file error.  

From looking at the timestamps on the compile logs, the problem seems to be that the the call to check for compile errors is coming after the org.eclipse.test has been compiled.  I don't understand why this is happening because the it is listed to occur sequentially after the tests and other features have been compiled. I'm investigating.  

As for the org.eclipse.test plugin, from looking at the generated build script, it appears that the swt fragments are not appearing on the classpath of the generated build.xml, but they are in earlier builds that use the old pde build.  I'll talk to Andrew about how to get around this since this feature is assembled using the packager, not like the other cases we have seen.

Talked to Andrew and he did some further investigation.  It turns out that the 3.4 stream org.eclipse.osgi is not resolving the swt fragments correctly.  He is following up with the Austin Equinox team for more information.  I'll run a test build with a 3.3.1 osgi in basebuilder to determine if the fragments appear on the classpath for the projects that have this issue.

The OSGi issue was resolved in bug 207500.

The problems with the compile error not showing up in our builder was due to the fact that the plugin org.eclipse.test is compiled twice in our builder, once in the org.eclipse.sdk.tests feature and once for the test framework. Due to the nature of the bug 207500, the swt fragments were resolving with one compile, but not the other.  

I've set noclean=true in our builder for the second feature that includes the org.eclipse.test plugin to avoid missing compile errors in the future. Thanks David, good catch :-)

It is indirectly referenced from required .class files  The type org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Shell cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files  The method getDisplay() is undefined for the type Shell
